description.narrative: The Fair, Green and Global Alliance (FGG) aims to increase the power and decision-making influence of organised, mobilised and informed civil society, especially women, to advance fair and green trade and value chains. FGG believes that poverty, inequality and exclusion are caused by power asymmetries. We see the unprecedented power of capital over people and planet as the primary obstacle impeding realisation of fair and green trade and value chains. The FGG programme focuses on recalibrating power within the global architecture of trade and value chains by amplifying the voices of targeted rights-holders – small producers and traders, workers, fishers, rural and Indigenous peoples, religious and ethnic minorities, and migrants, especially the women and youth among them – who are practising, claiming or defending human rights and fair and green economic practices, and/or whose rights are being ignored, threatened or violated by corporations and/or governments. We aim to transform social relations so that these rights-holders’ voices are heard and heeded. FGG’s eight members (ActionAid, Both ENDS, Clean Clothes Campaign, IT for Change, Milieudefensie/Friends of the Earth International/Friends of the Earth Europe, Samdhana Institute, SOMO and the Transnational Institute) cooperate with some 1000+ partners and allies in our many worldwide networks to strengthen collective capacities to advance a common vision of fair and green trade and value chains.
agenda-setting, momentum-building and increased support
# key actors (government, private sector, other) who put FGG policy/practice recommendations on their agendas (e.g. meetings, debates, media coverage)

comment.narrative:
(1) Meta (formerly Facebook) (1) invited IT for Change to provide expert inputs on the techno-design architecture and community guidelines of the Facebook app, an important step towards securing and strengthening women’s participation online and thereby ensuring civic space remain open and conducive to the promotion of gender justice goals. In October 2021, IT for Change was invited to provide inputs to the Facebook Oversight Board’s policy advisory on the sharing of private residential information on the platform. (x, g)
(1) The Karnataka (a state in India) Additional Secretary for e-Governance cited an oped written by IT for Change on the Karnataka State Open Data Policy framework to allay civil society concerns about Big Tech capture of public data sets. This came after IT for Change, in collaboration with DataMeet and Environment Support Group, pushed for action against this policy framework , which was announced without public consultation. IT for Change raised a range of concerns around the policy – the lack of public consultation, anonymization being an insufficient safeguard for citizen privacy in data sharing arrangements, and the issues of data monetization as a violation of the state’s fiduciary responsibility. The State Government of Karnataka in India, decided to revisit its Open Data Policy framework following these efforts. (x)
(1) 9 media outlets covered and highlighted talking points forwarded by IT for Change’s campaigns with unions and CSOs in India against the Reserve Back of India (RBI) proposal to proceed with licenses for corporations to run parallel financial infrastructures on a for-profit basis.
(1) The UNCTAD Digital Economy Report, 2021 (1) has cited several of IT for Change’s research and reports on digital economy governance and acknowledged contributions made by IT for Change in the report.
(1) In August 2021, the Paris Peace Forum, (an initiative of the French Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs) set up in 2018 to promote multistakeholder dialogue on critical global governance challenges, for the first time invited IT for Change to join the Global South and North Convergences and Divergences Working Group on algorithmic governance. As part of the working group, participating in close to 5 meetings with leading academics, technologists, civil society members, and activists in the domain of data and AI governance from across the world, IT for Change developed a futuristic roadmap for a global AI constitutionalism, which has been included in a key paper brought out by the group.
(1) A ten member UN expert group that supports the UN’s Technology Facilitation Mechanism invited IT for Change to be a member and has taken on board IT for Change’s recommendations in developing the agenda around digital economy and infrastructure issues for the upcoming Science, Technology and Innovation forum in May 2022.
(1) The Government of Kerala (a state in India) (1) invited IT for Change into dialogue to develop public policy frameworks through mapping of good practices in platform cooperativism, and provision of social security to knowledge workers, key agendas IT for Change has advocated for through research and policy work, for kick starting public initiatives in December 2021.
(1) The ILO governing body (1) in 2021, recognized the concept of workers’ data rights, which IT for Change has worked on and promoted as a critical area for labor rights in the digital economy was by, and has tabled the issue to be discussed in the 2022 International Labour Conference.
(1) IT for Change was invited to provide strategic directions for programmatic work of two leading philanthropic agencies on digital and data economy issues as expert advisers in 2021.
(1) IT for Change’s efforts on including the concept of ‘worker share in data value’ into labor agendas was taken up by two major union federations including the Public Services International (PSI) and International Transport Workers Federation (ITF) .
(1) Cornell University included in its reading material, a journal article published by IT for Change on Contextualising Wages for Housework for Indian Society and Digitalising Economy (g).
(1) A key report undertaken by IT for Change on Socializing Data Value, was included in Evegny Morozov’s Syllabus, a widely followed, curated weekly reading list.
(1) 170 civil society groups endorsed an an Open Letter to the UNSG , developed by IT for Change as part of the Just Net Coalition, opposing the High Level Multistakeholder Body for global digital governance, urging him to shelve plans for a High Level Multistakeholder Body which, if set up, can be expected to become the default apex global digital governance and policy body, a move that would increase corporate capture over digital governance processes and sidestep space for CSO participation and inputs.

In 2022, we aim for at least 3 actors (central government, ministries and state governments in India but also important important multilateral bodies such as the UNCTAD and the ILO) to incorporate policy recommendations on inclusive and fair digital economies, data, platform and AI governance, corporate regulation through the UN Binding Treaty and protecting worker rights in digital value chains on their agenda.

description.narrative: agenda-setting, momentum-building and increased support
# of instances in which the recommendation a key actor puts on its agenda aims to contribute to expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: Of these 3 actors, we aim for at least 1 actor (multilateral/other actor/key decision makers in governments) to put our recommendations on defending/expanding civic space on their agenda. We expect this will concern, among others, the engagement of civil society in digital trade policy implicating worker rights and public services.

description.narrative: agenda-setting, momentum-building and increased support
# of instances in which the recommendation a key actor puts on its agenda aims to contribute to gender justice

comment.narrative: Of these 3 actors, we aim for 1 actor to put our recommendation on gender equality on their agenda, mainly concerning the inclusion of women in the digital economy, the gendered modus operadi of platform capitalism, and integrating a gender-perspective in policies governing the digital economy, including data and AI governance.

description.narrative: governments increasing democratic decision-making
# instances in which key actors adopt and/or implement FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative: Several digital trade and e-commerce processes that IT for Change has been actively part of are still open and we have laid the ground work for important legislation to be passed in the coming years of the program duration.

In 2022, we aim for at least 1 instance, where a government institution from India or similar decision maker from Asia/Africa will adopt our recommendations on inclusive and fair trade and investment agreements for the governance of digital trade, that protects workers rights and preserves the regulatory capacities of developing countries.

description.narrative: governments increasing democratic decision-making
# key actors who support and/or promote FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative: The Ministerial Declaration of G-77 group of developing countries to the UNCTAD process in 2021, employed the term ‘digital industrialization’. This is the first time this term has been used in an official document. IT for Change has long advocated for this concept, especially in the context of developing countries through various documents and meetings at the South Centre, Geneva.

In 2022, we aim for 1 actor (likely policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendations on trade agreements, with specific reference to the place of worker rights and the regulatory capacities of developing countries.

description.narrative: governments increasing democratic decision-making
# of instances in which the adopted and/or implemented policies/practices by key actors contribute to expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for a government institution from India or similar decision maker from Asia/Africa to adopt our policy recommendation for the expansion of input spaces and mechanisms for civil society actors into the digital trade space

comment.narrative: In 2022, we aim for one instance in which a government institution from India adopts our recommendations on on gender-responsive digital trade rules and policies that expand the scope of women’s participation in global digital value chains.

description.narrative: governments regulating the private sector
# instances in which key actors adopt and/or implement FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative: (1) Meta (formerly Facebook) (1), facing pressure from policy makers, civil society and users at large, rolled back a critical change to its data privacy policy with respect to Whatsapp, a move which in effect, would have given Facebook unparalleled control over user data and compromised the privacy of millions who use the service. IT for Change was part of a global campaign, Save Whatsaap, which worked with civil society and raised public awareness on this issue. (x)
In 2022, we aim for at least 2 instances, where a government institution from India will adopt our recommendations for governance of the digital economy and regulation of Big Tech corporations.

description.narrative: governments regulating the private sector
# key actors who support and/or promote FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative:
(1) The Indian Ministry of Electronics and Information Technology (MeitY)’s (1) revised draft law framework on non-personal data came out in 2021, which includes significant concepts forwarded by IT for Change for the regulation of data in the context of the digital economy.
(1) IT for Change was part of the global Make Amazon Pay Campaign, supported by CSOs and unions around the world in November 2021. The campaign was widely shared and amplified on twitter with key MEPs and parliamentarians (1) lending support to the cause.
(1) The Special Rapporteur on the Right to Freedom of Speech and Expression (1) for the General Assembly Report on Gender Justice has cited IT for Change’s submission (citation 112) in her report to argue that the rising tide of online gender-based violence, harassment, trolling, doxxing and other harmful activities shows how social media platforms are not treating online gender-based violence with the urgency, seriousness, and resources it requires. (x,g)

In 2022, we aim for 2 actors (policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendations on governing corporate conduct and businesses in the digital economy, with specific reference to the UN Binding Treaty, and the governance of Big Tech companies and platforms operating in the Global South.

description.narrative: governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sector actors increasing policy space and support for fair and green practices
# instances in which key actors adopt and/or implement FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative: The Reserve Bank of India decided to defer its proposed decision to make available NUE (new umbrella entities) licenses for private corporations, which would have opened the pathway to parallel financial infrastructures on a for-profit basis and weakened the existing innovative financial public infrastructure. IT for Change pushed for this outcome through advocacy efforts with major trade unions and CSOs.
In 2022, we hope that in at least 1 instance, a government institution from India will adopt our recommendations on creating enabling national digital infrastructure policies for fair value chains.

description.narrative: governments, government-backed agencies, donors, private sector actors increasing policy space and support for fair and green practices
# key actors who support and/or promote FGG policy/practice recommendations

comment.narrative: IT for Change did a lot of groundwork in the area with inputs into key policy processes concerning national infrastructure policies on the digital economy in India including on draft laws, frameworks and policies for digital health, education, agriculture, finance etc. However, since these policy processes are currently still open, the impact of this work remains to be assessed.
In 2022, we aim for 3 actors (policymaker from India) to support our policy recommendations on enabling national infrastructure policies on the digital economy in India.

process
learning sessions organised by FGG members and partner organisations

comment.narrative: As a new member coming into an alliance with a ten year old history, learning has been a key priority for IT for Change in 2021. Through the year, we have had opportunities to use the FGG mandate to broaden understanding of the impacts of digitalization to value chains and global south development among our partners including unions and CSOs through multiple webinars, workshops, meetings and smaller discussions. IT for Change has also focused on broadening the understanding of these issues within the alliance through online learning sessions with FGG alliance members such as Centre for Research on Multinational Corporations (SOMO) and Transnational Institute (TNI) including a crash course on big tech and the Global South. In turn and equally, IT for Change has benefited from these interactions and been able to integrate critical insights and learnings from the work of partners and alliance members.

We will organize learning sessions on digital economy issues and their intersections with value chains for FGG consortium members as well as partner organizations.. We also view the opportunity to engage with long term partners as well as new members to our networks in the FGG program as a way to expand our learning with respect to issues, strategies and responses. Our work will be informed and modified by these collaborative processes.

As a new member coming into an alliance with a ten year old history, learning has been a key priority for IT for Change in 2021. Through the year, we have had opportunities to use the FGG mandate to broaden understanding of the impacts of digitalization to value chains and global south development among our partners including unions and CSOs through multiple webinars, workshops, meetings and smaller discussions. IT for Change has also focused on broadening the understanding of these issues within the alliance through online learning sessions with FGG alliance members such as Centre for Research on Multinational Corporations (SOMO) and Transnational Institute (TNI) including a crash course on big tech and the Global South. In turn and equally, IT for Change has benefited from these interactions and been able to integrate critical insights and learnings from the work of partners and alliance members.

description.narrative: process
lines of work in which FGG members and partners build upon gender analysis and incorporate gender justice in their strategy

comment.narrative: Gender justice is a critical component of all the work that IT for Change has undertaken under the FGG program. We have strived to bring concerns of gender justice into our policy work on e-commerce and Big Tech. Specifically, we started exploratory work in 2021 on research on women led MSMEs in digital value chains, gender and e-commerce, and gender issues with respect to women workers in the digital economy. This compliments several lines of work that IT for Change has been pursuing focussing on the intersections of In 2021, we also had an exclusive focus on gender justice through our two-day online Institute on Feminist Perspectives on Digital Economy and Society which included participation from India, Philippines, Indonesia and Uganda.

Gender justice is a critical component of all the work that we will be doing under the FGG program. Specifically, we will be focussing on research on women in digital value chains, gender and e-commerce, gender issues wrt women workers in the digital economy.

Gender justice is a critical component of all the work that IT for Change has undertaken under the FGG program. We have strived to bring concerns of gender justice into our policy work on e-commerce and Big Tech. Specifically, we started exploratory work in 2021 on research on women led MSMEs in digital value chains, gender and e-commerce, and gender issues with respect to women workers in the digital economy. This compliments several lines of work that IT for Change has been pursuing focussing on the intersections of In 2021, we also had an exclusive focus on gender justice through our two-day online Institute on Feminist Perspectives on Digital Economy and Society which included participation from India, Philippines, Indonesia and Uganda.

description.narrative: process
the extent to and ways in which FGG involves local groups in the design and implementation of the FGG programme

comment.narrative: IT for Change worked with local partners closely to seek inputs and contextualize work done through FGG. This included working with CS actors in India to respond to important advocacy opportunities around worker rights in the digital economy, as well as responding to articulations for knowledge building on specific issues, support with policy inputs etc.

We will work with local partners closely to seek inputs and contextualize various collaborative iniatitives planned under FGG. Both at the design and implementation stage of projects and iniaiatives planned under FGG, we will reach out to local partners for consultations and discussions . We will work with partners in India, Indonesia, Philippines and broadly in Asia-Pacific and Latin America

IT for Change worked with local partners closely to seek inputs and contextualize work done through FGG. This included working with CS actors in India to respond to important advocacy opportunities around worker rights in the digital economy, as well as responding to articulations for knowledge building on specific issues, support with policy inputs etc.

description.narrative: strengthened capacities
# of CSOs included in the FGG programme

comment.narrative: Up to 48 CSOs were included in IT for Change’s efforts under the FGG program in 2021
In 2022, we aim to include a total of 10 CSOs in our activities under the FGG program

description.narrative: strengthened capacities
# targeted civil society actors that lobby and advocate for improved policies and practices in trade and value chains and advance fair and green practices based on capacities mutually developed

comment.narrative:
(1) With expert support and inputs from IT for Change, the Alliance for Sustainable and Holistic Agriculture's (ASHA's) (1) developed a response to the Government of India's Ministry of Agriculture, Cooperation and Farmer Welfare on their Consultation Paper on India Digital System of Agriculture in June 2021.
(3) In collaboration with IT for Change, two major unions in India (UNI Global and All India State Bank of India Staff Federation) and an Indian CSO network (Joint Action Committee against Foreign Retail and e-commerce) galvanized a campaign in June 2021 against a decision of the Reserve Back of India (RBI) to proceed with licenses for corporations to run parallel financial infrastructures loan a for-profit basis. As part of this, IT for Change worked with the above mentioned partners on a joint letter and press release.
(21) In collaboration with IT for Change, Indian digital rights CSO, Center for Internet and Society (1), co-organized a strategy meeting on the Indian Government's newly launched e-Shram portal, designed to deliver targeted social security benefits to informal sector workers. This strategy meeting brought together 21 CSO representatives along with researchers and academics, whose contributions were distilled by IT for Change and CIS to develop a policy brief Civil Society Agenda for e-Shram in December 2021. This document was widely circulated, as indicated by the 207 downloads recorded from the IT for Change website, along with additional views/downloads from the Centre for Internet and Society website.

In 2022, we aim for 5 CSOs, located mainly in Asia-Pacific (India), Latin America and Africa to lobby and advocate for improving trade and investment agreements, with a focus on digital trade rules and chapters. Our focus will be on 1. ensuring treaties do not undermine workers rights nor the regulatory spaces of developing countries to pursue their own digital development agendas, 2. appropriate corporate regulation and data governance regimes 3. infrastructural policy initiatives and alternative models . This will be done through knowledge building in the domain, joint strategizing and coordination.

description.narrative: strengthened capacities
# targeted civil society actors with strengthened capacities contributing to and/or relevant for lobby and advocacy aiming at expanding/defending civic space

comment.narrative: We will strengthen capacities of all 10 CSOs towards expanding/defending civic space. We envision this goal to be an outcome of work done through our capacity development initiatives, our knowledge partnerships as well as joint strategizing activities on digital justice issues. Through this work, we will enable CSOs to assert/amplify their voices in fora where policies on the digital economy are being debated – both at the national and international levels. An important focus of our work will be to reclaim global governance spaces around the digital for civil society voice and deliberative democartic processes that have increasingly fallen prey to corporature capture.

description.narrative: strengthened capacities
# targeted civil society actors with strengthened capacities for lobbying and advocacy

comment.narrative:
(16) 16 CSO actors from LLMUMICs, including from India, Philippines and Indonesia strengthened their understanding of feminist perspectives on digital economy and society by participating in a two-day online institute organized by IT for Change. The institute was the first of its kind to provide conceptual and analytical inputs and in-depth capacity building on the issue, covering diverse topics such as the platform economy and macroeconomic shifts, and feminist agendas for policy in the digital economy and society. The institute also focussed on addressing the critical issue of voice and claims-making in a platformized society. (x, g)
(2) CSOs from Asia and Latin America improved their knowledge on Digital Sequence Information (DSI) through a capacity building webinar on Digital Sequence Information (DSI), Biodiversity as Big Data: How DSI fits into Global Data Flows, organized by the Global Youth Biodiversity Network in collaboration with Third World Network in August 2021, for which IT for Change provided content and programming inputs. The session addressed how gene sequences and data science are transforming biological research, and how digital sequencing of information relates to fairness and equity for developing countries, especially for farmers and indigenous peoples.
(1) The People’s Working Group on Multistakeholderism, which IT for Change is part of, was able to further a critical perspective on the multistakeholder capture of the digital governance process as part of a coordinated campaign targeting the annual forum of the World Economic Forum in January 2021. IT for Change supported the campaign through the development of knowledge outputs. (x)
(2) CSOs working effectively towards common strategic goals on science, technology and development in different parts of the UN were able to strengthen their capacities on digital issues through a CSO Briefing in Science, Technology and Development Agenda at the UN for CSOs in May 2021, organized by the ETC Group and the CSO FfD Group, where IT for Change provided inputs.
(1) CSOs in the ICT sector were able to broaden their knowledge on digital sector Business Responsibility and Sustainability Reporting at a CSO consultation jointly organized by UNDP India and Partners for Change, where IT for Change was invited to provide inputs on non-financial reporting guidelines for digital economy actors.
(1) CSO actors were able to expand their knowledge on digital economy issues and strengthen their engagement at the Consultation of Civil Society with the Co-Chairs of the Preparatory Committee for the Fifth United Nations Conference on the Least Developed Countries (LDC5) in May 2021. Towards this, IT for Change, as part of the Just Net Coalition and in collaboration with Social Watch, supported input development outlining key concerns for digital economy for LDCs.
(21) 21 CSOs actors expanded their knowledge and were able to contribute insights to an important policy brief at a strategy meeting and co-organized by IT for Change in collaboration with Indian digital rights CSO, Center for Internet and Society on the Indian Government's newly launched e-Shram portal, designed to deliver targeted social security benefits to informal sector workers.
(1) The Alliance for Sustainable and Holistic Agriculture developed a response to the Government of India's Ministry of Agriculture, Cooperation and Farmer Welfare on their Consultation Paper on India Digital System of Agriculture in June 2021, with expert support and inputs from IT for Change.
(3) Two major unions in India (UNI Global and All India State Bank of India Staff Federation) and an Indian CSO network (Joint Action Committee against Foreign Retail and e-commerce) , galvanized a campaign in June 2021 against a decision of the Reserve Back of India (RBI) to proceed with licenses for corporations to run parallel financial infrastructures loan a for-profit basis. IT for Change supported these efforts through coordination and provision of expert inputs.

We aim for 10 civil society actors, located in India, Asia-Pacific, Latin America and Africa to have strengthened their capacities to recognize and grasp digital intersections within global value chains and advocate for fairer outcomes. This includes for instance worker rights for emerging digital economy contexts, appropriate data policies, regulation of corporate conduct of tech companies, better digital taxation and competition policies.

description.narrative: strengthened capacities
# targeted civil society actors with strengthened capacities relevant to advance gender justice

comment.narrative: Of these 10 CSOs, we will strengthen the capacities of 3 CSOs (In India and globally) to better lobby and advocacy for gender justice in the digital economy, through weaving in gender justice components such as women’s economic rights and equal participation in digital value chains, into our capacity building initiatives and knowledge exercises.
